column2: The Constitutional Convention

With our freedom finally won, it is time to decide upon the fate of our nation. Numerous scholars and thinkers are collecting in $CAPITAL$ in a Constitutional Convention where they will decide how our new country is to be run.
We the people...

The first matter being discussed at the convention is how much authority the central government should have. The choice has been narrowed down to three options but greater centralisation is sure to upset the States.
The government should only deal with other Nations
The government should collaborate with the States
The government has no need for States

With the government's role having been determined, it is time to deliberate on who can participate in it. The deputies are arguing between popular democracy, and elite democracy or a strong man in charge of everything.
Only a strong man can hold this together
The more sophisticated citizens should decide
Everyone should participate in decisionmaking

The final issue to be determined in our constitution is that of slavery. On the one side, deputies argue that all men were created equal and deserve liberty while others believe that slaves are an essential component in the economy.
Slaves and their children are legal property
Slaves are necessary but their children should be freed
No man should suffer to be treated as an object

The final issue to be determined in our constitution is that of the condition of the natives. On the one side, deputies argue that they should be welcomed into our society as equals while others believe that they should be removed from profitable land.
The natives have no place in this country
They can stay if they learn to be proper Luisianans
We will build a better country if we work together
A New World

With the birth of our country over a decade removed, a sense of normality has descended and there are those who are interested in revising the constitution. In the meantime, it appears that the states have curbed their more centrifugal instincts.
